subject: Re: [junit] Strange request: examples of "beautiful" test code
msgSnippet: I think that JUnit3 test code is more beautiful than its competitors and successors because it s appropriately minimal. It makes good things easy and bad
messageBody:
I think that JUnit3 test code is more beautiful than its competitors and
successors because it's appropriately minimal. It makes good things easy
and bad things difficult.

Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

>On 11/27/06, Bradley, Todd <todd.bradley@...> wrote:
>
>
>>In my book, a beautiful unit test is one that tests as much as possible,
>>as simply as possible. I don't usually associate "clever" with "keep is
>>simple stupid" but maybe that's just me. I think a beautiful JUnit test
>>would be one that uses both inheritance and the "parameterized test
>>case" pattern to be as short and sweet (and therefore maintainable) as
>>possible.
>>
>>
>
>
>Personally (and as you say, code beauty is in the beholder's eye), I
>wouldn't count test code that uses the parameterized test case pattern as
>"beautiful", because this design pattern only exists to address a limitation
>in JUnit 3, and for that reason, it obfuscates the code more than it
>prettifies it (one of the reasons why "modern" test frameworks let you pass
>parameters directly to your test methods).
>
>I would give a similar "thumbs down" to the "exception design pattern": it
>adds a lot of noise to the test code, thereby hiding its true intent (and
>similarly, it's been addressed in modern test frameworks by letting users
>specify that an exception is expected from the test method directly in the
>annotation).
>
>
>
